Decreased PSV, delayed systolic upstroke (tardus-parvus waveform), and decreased RI.
respuesta_correcta: Decreased PSV, delayed systolic upstroke (tardus-parvus waveform), and decreased RI.
concept_to_study: Hemodynamics distal to renal artery stenosis
explicacion_openai: Distal to a hemodynamically significant stenosis (in this case, in the kidney parenchyma), the flow experiences changes due to the upstream obstruction. The Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) will be decreased due to reduced flow volume. The systolic upstroke will be delayed and blunted, creating a characteristic "tardus-parvus" waveform. Importantly, the Resistive Index (RI) in the kidney parenchyma often decreases (becomes lower) because the kidney autoregulates by dilating its distal arterioles to try and maintain flow, thus reducing peripheral resistance. This low resistance is an attempt to compensate for the proximal stenosis. An increased RI would be seen in conditions causing increased resistance, such as medical renal disease or acute obstruction. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and renal artery duplex hemodynamics).

enunciado: The sonographic appearance of an acute deep venous thrombus (DVT) on B-mode imaging, differentiating it from a chronic thrombus, typically includes:
opciones: Brightly echogenic, heterogeneous, and well-organized thrombus.
Hypoechoic or anechoic, homogeneous, and poorly attached thrombus.
Calcified, retracting thrombus with significant vein wall thickening.
Multiple venous collaterals and valve immobility.
respuesta_correcta: Hypoechoic or anechoic, homogeneous, and poorly attached thrombus.
explicacion_openai: Acute DVT typically appears hypoechoic (darker) or even anechoic (black) on B-mode imaging, indicating a fresh, unorganized thrombus composed mostly of blood components. It tends to be homogeneous in texture and may appear poorly attached to the vein wall or mobile. Over time, as a thrombus ages and organizes, it becomes more echogenic (brighter), heterogeneous, retracts, and becomes firmly attached to the vein wall, often leading to vein wall thickening and the development of collaterals (features of chronic DVT). Calcification is rare in venous thrombus. (Refer to SVU Intersocietal Standards for the Performance of Lower Extremity Venous Duplex Ultrasound and "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound").

enunciado: A patient complains of chronic leg swelling, aching, and skin discoloration around the ankles. A venous duplex ultrasound is performed. What is the primary sonographic finding that indicates significant venous insufficiency?
opciones: Complete compressibility of the superficial femoral vein.
Absence of flow in the common femoral vein.
Venous reflux (backward flow) lasting greater than a specified duration (e.g., > 0.5 seconds) after distal augmentation or Valsalva.
High Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the popliteal vein.
respuesta_correcta: Venous reflux (backward flow) lasting greater than a specified duration (e.g., > 0.5 seconds) after distal augmentation or Valsalva.
explicacion_openai: Venous insufficiency is characterized by incompetent venous valves, which allow blood to flow backward (reflux) due to gravity and increased pressure. The primary sonographic indicator is the detection of this reflux, quantified by its duration. When using techniques like distal augmentation (squeezing the calf) or the Valsalva maneuver, normal valves should prevent significant backward flow. Reflux lasting longer than a specific threshold (e.g., typically >0.5 seconds for superficial veins and >1.0 second for deep veins, though thresholds vary slightly) signifies valvular incompetence. Complete compressibility indicates patency, not insufficiency. Absence of flow suggests thrombosis. High PSV is not a direct indicator of insufficiency. (Refer to SVU Intersocietal Standards for the Performance of Lower Extremity Venous Duplex Ultrasound for Venous Insufficiency).

enunciado: A patient presents with acute onset swelling and pain in the right arm after intense exercise. Venous duplex ultrasound of the upper extremity reveals a thrombus occluding the subclavian vein. This clinical presentation and finding are highly suggestive of:
opciones: Paget-Schroetter Syndrome (effort thrombosis of the subclavian vein).
Superficial thrombophlebitis of the cephalic vein.
respuesta_correcta: Paget-Schroetter Syndrome (effort thrombosis of the subclavian vein).
explicacion_openai: Paget-Schroetter Syndrome is a form of upper extremity deep venous thrombosis (UEDVT) that occurs spontaneously, typically in young, otherwise healthy individuals, often associated with repetitive, strenuous overhead arm activity (e.g., athletes, manual laborers). This "effort thrombosis" is due to compression of the subclavian vein in the thoracic outlet. Acute onset swelling and pain in the arm, coupled with subclavian vein thrombus, fits this diagnosis. Axillary artery aneurysm is an arterial issue. SVC Syndrome involves compression of the SVC, leading to bilateral upper extremity swelling. Superficial thrombophlebitis would be in superficial veins. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and vascular surgery/medicine texts).

enunciado: A patient presents with left leg swelling and pain. Venous duplex of the left leg is negative for DVT. However, Color Doppler and spectral analysis of the left common iliac vein reveal turbulent flow and evidence of extrinsic compression by the overlying right common iliac artery. This finding is consistent with:
explicacion_openai: May-Thurner Syndrome (also known as Iliac Vein Compression Syndrome) occurs when the left common iliac vein is compressed by the overlying right common iliac artery against the lumbar spine. This chronic compression can lead to intimal damage, fibrosis, and a predisposition to DVT in the left leg, even without acute thrombus at the time of exam. The sonographic findings of extrinsic compression and turbulent flow in the left common iliac vein, in a patient with unexplained left leg swelling, are classic for this syndrome. Popliteal venous aneurysm is a focal dilatation. Post-thrombotic syndrome is a consequence of prior DVT, not the initial cause. Superficial thrombophlebitis is in superficial veins. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and vascular medicine texts).

enunciado: A patient complains of arm pain, numbness, and pallor with overhead arm movements. Duplex ultrasound of the subclavian artery reveals a normal waveform at rest, but with arm abduction and external rotation, the Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) significantly increases, and the waveform becomes severely dampened or absent. This is characteristic of:
opciones: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) with arterial compression.
respuesta_correcta: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) with arterial compression.
explicacion_openai: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) is a condition caused by compression of the neurovascular bundle (brachial plexus, subclavian artery, and/or subclavian vein) in the thoracic outlet space. Arterial TOS is characterized by positional compression of the subclavian artery, leading to changes in flow. A normal waveform at rest, with significant changes (increased velocity, dampened, or absent flow) in provocative positions (like arm abduction and external rotation), is the key sonographic finding. Aneurysm is a dilatation. Occlusion would show absent flow at rest. Vasospasm would typically affect distal arteries of the hand and digits. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and SVU practice guidelines for Upper Extremity Arterial Duplex).

enunciado: A 60-year-old patient with a history of smoking and diabetes presents with pain in the calf after walking short distances, relieved by rest. A lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound is performed. What is the most common and expected finding in a patient with classic claudication symptoms?
opciones: Significant atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion in the femoropopliteal segment.
Dilatation (aneurysm) of the superficial femoral artery.
Normal triphasic waveforms throughout the entire leg.
respuesta_correcta: Significant atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion in the femoropopliteal segment.
explicacion_openai: Claudication (pain in the muscles during exercise, relieved by rest) is the classic symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The most common underlying cause is atherosclerosis, leading to hemodynamically significant stenoses or occlusions. The femoropopliteal segment (Superficial Femoral Artery and Popliteal Artery) is a very frequent site for atherosclerotic disease in claudicants. An ABI > 1.3 might indicate calcified vessels. Aneurysms are dilatations, not the primary cause of claudication. Normal triphasic waveforms would rule out significant PAD. (Refer to SVU Intersocietal Standards for the Performance of Lower Extremity Arterial Duplex Ultrasound and vascular medicine texts).

enunciado: A patient complains of severe abdominal pain that typically occurs 30-60 minutes after eating, often described as "fear of food," leading to weight loss. A mesenteric duplex ultrasound is ordered. What specific finding in the celiac axis and/or superior mesenteric artery (SMA) would support a diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia?
opciones: Markedly decreased Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the celiac axis.
High Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV > 275 cm/s in SMA, > 200 cm/s in celiac) with post-stenotic turbulence.
Retrograde flow in the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).
Absent flow in the splenic artery.
respuesta_correcta: High Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV > 275 cm/s in SMA, > 200 cm/s in celiac) with post-stenotic turbulence.
explicacion_openai: Chronic mesenteric ischemia, often presenting with postprandial abdominal pain ("abdominal angina") and weight loss, is typically caused by significant stenoses or occlusions in at least two of the three main mesenteric arteries (celiac axis, SMA, IMA). High Peak Systolic Velocities (PSV), above established thresholds (e.g., >275 cm/s for SMA, >200 cm/s for celiac axis), along with post-stenotic turbulence and altered waveforms, are key sonographic indicators of hemodynamically significant stenosis. Decreased PSV might indicate occlusion but not stenosis severity directly. Retrograde IMA flow can be a compensatory mechanism, but high PSV indicates the direct stenosis. Absent flow in the splenic artery might indicate celiac occlusion but is less specific for chronic mesenteric ischemia than high PSV in the main trunks. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and SVU practice guidelines for Mesenteric Duplex).

enunciado: A 35-year-old female with new-onset hypertension is referred for a renal duplex ultrasound. The sonographer identifies a "string of beads" appearance in the mid-to-distal main renal artery with associated focal areas of increased velocity. This is the characteristic sonographic finding for:
opciones: Renal artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis.
explicacion_openai: Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) is a non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory arterial disease that primarily affects medium-sized arteries, most commonly the renal arteries (causing renovascular hypertension) and carotid arteries. Its classic angiographic and sonographic appearance is a "string of beads" or "string of pearls" pattern, representing alternating areas of stenosis and small aneurysmal dilatations. This finding, especially in a young female with new-onset hypertension, is highly characteristic of FMD. Renal artery aneurysm is a focal dilatation. Dissection involves a tear in the wall. Atherosclerosis would appear as plaque. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and renal artery duplex guidelines).

enunciado: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with ascites and splenomegaly. A hepatoportal duplex ultrasound is performed. Which of the following findings would be most consistent with portal hypertension?
opciones: Hepatofugal (away from liver) flow in the main portal vein.
High Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the hepatic arteries.
Normal triphasic flow in the hepatic veins.
Absence of flow in the splenic vein.
respuesta_correcta: Hepatofugal (away from liver) flow in the main portal vein.
explicacion_openai: Portal hypertension is a serious complication of chronic liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis), characterized by abnormally high pressure in the portal venous system. A classic and highly significant sonographic sign of severe portal hypertension is hepatofugal flow (flow directed away from the liver) in the main portal vein, indicating reversal of the normal hepatopetal (towards the liver) flow direction. This reversal occurs as the body tries to decompress the high pressure system, often developing collateral veins. High PSV in hepatic arteries might indicate compensatory arterial flow but is not a direct sign of portal hypertension. Normal triphasic flow in hepatic veins would be unusual in significant liver disease; hepatic veins often show monophasic or dampened flow in cirrhosis. Absence of flow in the splenic vein suggests splenic vein thrombosis, which can contribute to portal hypertension but is not the most consistent finding for generalized portal hypertension. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" and hepatobiliary ultrasound texts).

enunciado: Which flap uses tissue from the rectus abdominis muscle and adjacent soft tissue for reconstruction?
opciones: None of the options are correct
explicacion_openai: A TRAM flap (transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap) involves transferring skin, fat, and the rectus abdominis muscle from the lower abdomen to reconstruct the breast after mastectomy.

enunciado: Which flap spares the abdominal muscle, relying only on skin, fat, and perforating vessels?
explicacion_openai: The DIEP flap (deep inferior epigastric perforator flap) preserves the rectus abdominis muscle by harvesting skin and fat supplied by perforator vessels from the deep inferior epigastric artery.

enunciado: Which flap uses tissue from the rectus abdominis muscle and adjacent soft tissue for reconstruction?
opciones: None of the options are correct
explicacion_openai: A TRAM flap (transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap) involves transferring skin, fat, and the rectus abdominis muscle from the lower abdomen to reconstruct the breast after mastectomy.

enunciado: Which flap spares the abdominal muscle, relying only on skin, fat, and perforating vessels?
explicacion_openai: The DIEP flap (deep inferior epigastric perforator flap) preserves the rectus abdominis muscle by harvesting skin and fat supplied by perforator vessels from the deep inferior epigastric artery.

enunciado: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a clinical manifestation of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)?
explicacion_openai: Acute pulmonary embolism (PE) commonly presents with symptoms such as sudden onset dyspnea (shortness of breath), tachypnea (rapid breathing), pleuritic chest pain (pain that worsens with breathing), cough, and tachycardia (rapid heart rate). Bradycardia (slow heart rate) is less common than tachycardia in PE, as the body typically responds to hypoxemia and increased pulmonary vascular resistance with an increased heart rate.

enunciado: Which of the following clinical findings is LEAST likely to be associated with deep venous thrombosis (DVT)?
opciones: Warmth and erythema of the affected limb
Coldness and pallor of the affected limb
respuesta_correcta: Coldness and pallor of the affected limb
explicacion_openai: Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) typically causes venous congestion due to impaired venous return. This often leads to unilateral leg swelling, pain, warmth, and erythema (redness) of the affected limb. Coldness and pallor are signs more indicative of arterial insufficiency or occlusion, which affects arterial inflow, rather than venous outflow obstruction characteristic of DVT.

enunciado: Which of the following symptoms is LEAST characteristic of a pulmonary embolism (PE)?
explicacion_openai: Common clinical symptoms of pulmonary embolism (PE) include cough, hemoptysis (coughing up blood), dyspnea (shortness of breath), tachypnea, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and syncope (fainting). Severe epigastric pain is not a typical primary symptom of PE. While some patients might experience non-specific abdominal discomfort, it is not a characteristic manifestation.

enunciado: Which of the following is NOT a typical physical finding associated with deep venous thrombosis (DVT)?
opciones: Increased circumference of the affected limb
explicacion_openai: Physical findings suggestive of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) include unilateral leg swelling (leading to increased limb circumference), calf pain and tenderness, warmth, erythema, and sometimes a palpable venous cord or distended superficial veins due to collateral flow. Absent pedal pulses are indicative of arterial compromise and are not typically associated with DVT, which primarily affects venous return.

enunciado: Which of the following clinical findings is LEAST likely to be present in a patient with a pulmonary embolism (PE)?
explicacion_openai: Pulmonary embolism (PE) can manifest with various clinical signs, including hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels), tachycardia (rapid heart rate), anxiety, dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain. Wheezing, however, is a respiratory sound primarily associated with bronchospasm or airway obstruction (e.g., asthma, COPD) and is not a typical finding in PE. While other auscultatory findings like crackles might occur, wheezing is less characteristic.

enunciado: What is the most common complication of an arteriovenous fistula (AVF) for dialysis that an RVT sonographer should identify?
explicacion_openai: Stenosis is the most frequent complication leading to AVF dysfunction and eventual thrombosis.

enunciado: Which color or spectral Doppler finding is highly suggestive of significant stenosis in an AVF?
opciones: Low flow velocities throughout the vessel.
A significant focal increase in Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) with turbulence.
Presence of a triphasic flow pattern.
respuesta_correcta: A significant focal increase in Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) with turbulence.
explicacion_openai: Stenosis causes flow acceleration at the narrowed point, resulting in elevated velocities and distal turbulence.

enunciado: A post-EVAR patient presents with an enlarging aneurysmal sac and persistent flow within the aneurysm sac with no clear anastomotic leak. What type of endoleak is most likely?
explicacion_openai: Type II endoleaks are the most common and result from retrograde flow from collateral branches (such as lumbar or inferior mesenteric arteries) into the aneurysmal sac.

enunciado: When evaluating the patency and function of a lower extremity arterial bypass graft, what is the expected spectral Doppler flow pattern in a successful, non-stenotic graft?
opciones: Absence of audible or visible flow.
explicacion_openai: A well-functioning arterial bypass graft typically exhibits a biphasic or triphasic flow pattern, reflecting the high-resistance distal arterial bed, although in some cases with low-resistance beds, it can be biphasic.

enunciado: What is the primary purpose of an implanted Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) filter?
opciones: To prevent superior vena cava syndrome.
To improve lower extremity venous return.
explicacion_openai: IVC filters are designed to trap blood clots traveling from leg or pelvic veins, preventing them from reaching the lungs.

enunciado: Following venous ablation for great saphenous vein insufficiency, which sonographic finding is desirable to confirm a successful procedure?
opciones: Presence of biphasic flow within the vein.
Sclerosed and occluded vein, with no detectable flow.
respuesta_correcta: Sclerosed and occluded vein, with no detectable flow.
explicacion_openai: Successful ablation results in occlusion and fibrosis of the treated vein, eliminating abnormal reflux.

enunciado: An RVT sonographer is reviewing an operative report for a TIPS that mentions "intraprocedural stenosis treated with additional stent." What implication does this information have for sonographic follow-up?
opciones: No implications, as the stenosis was treated.
The need for less frequent sonographic evaluations.
An increased risk of re-stenosis or shunt dysfunction, requiring close surveillance.
respuesta_correcta: An increased risk of re-stenosis or shunt dysfunction, requiring close surveillance.
explicacion_openai: Any intraprocedural complication, even if resolved, may indicate a higher predisposition to future problems, necessitating closer follow-up.

enunciado: In a mature and functional AVF, how is the flow pattern described in the afferent artery (proximal to the anastomosis)?
explicacion_openai: The AVF creates a very low-resistance bed, causing the afferent artery to adopt a low-resistance flow pattern to supply the shunt.

enunciado: A patient with a functional AVF complains of pain, coldness, and weakness in the hand distal to the access. Which syndrome is most likely?
explicacion_openai: Steal syndrome occurs when a significant portion of arterial flow is "stolen" by the AVF, reducing perfusion to the distal tissues of the extremity.

enunciado: What is a common spectral Doppler finding in a TIPS that has developed clinically significant stenosis?
opciones: A uniform increase in velocities throughout the shunt.
Decreased peak velocity within the stent and possible reversal of portal vein flow.
Excessively high flow velocities (>200 cm/s) without focal acceleration.
respuesta_correcta: Decreased peak velocity within the stent and possible reversal of portal vein flow.
explicacion_openai: Stenosis in a TIPS reduces flow through the shunt, which can lead to a general decrease in stent velocities and reversal of portal flow as it seeks to decompress pressure.

enunciado: Which combination of sonographic findings in a renal transplant is highly suggestive of acute rejection?
opciones: Decreased cortical echogenicity and increased corticomedullary differentiation.
Increased cortical echogenicity, loss of corticomedullary differentiation, and elevated resistive indices (RI).
A low RI (<0.6) and dilated renal veins.
respuesta_correcta: Increased cortical echogenicity, loss of corticomedullary differentiation, and elevated resistive indices (RI).
concept_to_study: Renal Transplant Acute Rejection Sonographic Findings
explicacion_openai: Acute rejection often causes edema and inflammation, resulting in a brighter cortex, blurred distinction between cortex and medulla, and increased resistance to intrarenal blood flow.

enunciado: In the first few days post-liver transplant, what is the most severe vascular complication that can lead to early graft loss?
explicacion_openai: Hepatic artery thrombosis is a devastating complication that compromises the oxygen supply to the graft and can lead to ischemic liver failure.

enunciado: A patient with a femoropopliteal bypass graft presents with decreasing ankle-brachial indices (ABIs) and recurrent leg pain during walking. What is the most likely cause of this graft dysfunction?
explicacion_openai: Stenosis or thrombosis are the most common causes of graft dysfunction, restricting blood flow and causing ischemic symptoms like claudication and decreased ABIs.

enunciado: An operative report for a renal transplant indicates "end-to-end anastomosis of the graft renal artery to the recipient's internal iliac artery." What does this mean for the sonographic examination?
opciones: The sonographer will look for a side-to-side anastomosis between the graft renal artery and the internal iliac artery.
The sonographer will look for an anastomosis where the end of the graft renal artery is connected to the transected end of the internal iliac artery.
The anastomosis will be difficult to visualize due to its deep location.
The graft renal artery will be connected directly to the aorta.
respuesta_correcta: The sonographer will look for an anastomosis where the end of the graft renal artery is connected to the transected end of the internal iliac artery.
explicacion_openai: "End-to-end" means the end of one vessel is joined to the end of another, implying the recipient's internal iliac artery would have been ligated and divided.

enunciado: What is the most common complication of an arteriovenous fistula (AVF) for dialysis that an RVT sonographer should identify?
explicacion_openai: Stenosis is the most frequent complication leading to AVF dysfunction and eventual thrombosis.

enunciado: Which color or spectral Doppler finding is highly suggestive of significant stenosis in an AVF?
opciones: Low flow velocities throughout the vessel.
A significant focal increase in Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) with turbulence.
Presence of a triphasic flow pattern.
respuesta_correcta: A significant focal increase in Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) with turbulence.
explicacion_openai: Stenosis causes flow acceleration at the narrowed point, resulting in elevated velocities and distal turbulence.

enunciado: A post-EVAR patient presents with an enlarging aneurysmal sac and persistent flow within the aneurysm sac with no clear anastomotic leak. What type of endoleak is most likely?
explicacion_openai: Type II endoleaks are the most common and result from retrograde flow from collateral branches (such as lumbar or inferior mesenteric arteries) into the aneurysmal sac.

enunciado: When evaluating the patency and function of a lower extremity arterial bypass graft, what is the expected spectral Doppler flow pattern in a successful, non-stenotic graft?
opciones: Absence of audible or visible flow.
explicacion_openai: A well-functioning arterial bypass graft typically exhibits a biphasic or triphasic flow pattern, reflecting the high-resistance distal arterial bed, although in some cases with low-resistance beds, it can be biphasic.

enunciado: What is the primary purpose of an implanted Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) filter?
opciones: To prevent superior vena cava syndrome.
To improve lower extremity venous return.
explicacion_openai: IVC filters are designed to trap blood clots traveling from leg or pelvic veins, preventing them from reaching the lungs.

enunciado: Following venous ablation for great saphenous vein insufficiency, which sonographic finding is desirable to confirm a successful procedure?
opciones: Presence of biphasic flow within the vein.
Sclerosed and occluded vein, with no detectable flow.
respuesta_correcta: Sclerosed and occluded vein, with no detectable flow.
explicacion_openai: Successful ablation results in occlusion and fibrosis of the treated vein, eliminating abnormal reflux.

enunciado: An RVT sonographer is reviewing an operative report for a TIPS that mentions "intraprocedural stenosis treated with additional stent." What implication does this information have for sonographic follow-up?
opciones: No implications, as the stenosis was treated.
The need for less frequent sonographic evaluations.
An increased risk of re-stenosis or shunt dysfunction, requiring close surveillance.
respuesta_correcta: An increased risk of re-stenosis or shunt dysfunction, requiring close surveillance.
explicacion_openai: Any intraprocedural complication, even if resolved, may indicate a higher predisposition to future problems, necessitating closer follow-up.

enunciado: In a mature and functional AVF, how is the flow pattern described in the afferent artery (proximal to the anastomosis)?
explicacion_openai: The AVF creates a very low-resistance bed, causing the afferent artery to adopt a low-resistance flow pattern to supply the shunt.

enunciado: A patient with a functional AVF complains of pain, coldness, and weakness in the hand distal to the access. Which syndrome is most likely?
explicacion_openai: Steal syndrome occurs when a significant portion of arterial flow is "stolen" by the AVF, reducing perfusion to the distal tissues of the extremity.

enunciado: What is a common spectral Doppler finding in a TIPS that has developed clinically significant stenosis?
opciones: A uniform increase in velocities throughout the shunt.
Decreased peak velocity within the stent and possible reversal of portal vein flow.
Excessively high flow velocities (>200 cm/s) without focal acceleration.
respuesta_correcta: Decreased peak velocity within the stent and possible reversal of portal vein flow.
explicacion_openai: Stenosis in a TIPS reduces flow through the shunt, which can lead to a general decrease in stent velocities and reversal of portal flow as it seeks to decompress pressure.

enunciado: Which combination of sonographic findings in a renal transplant is highly suggestive of acute rejection?
opciones: Decreased cortical echogenicity and increased corticomedullary differentiation.
Increased cortical echogenicity, loss of corticomedullary differentiation, and elevated resistive indices (RI).
A low RI (<0.6) and dilated renal veins.
respuesta_correcta: Increased cortical echogenicity, loss of corticomedullary differentiation, and elevated resistive indices (RI).
concept_to_study: Renal Transplant Acute Rejection Sonographic Findings
explicacion_openai: Acute rejection often causes edema and inflammation, resulting in a brighter cortex, blurred distinction between cortex and medulla, and increased resistance to intrarenal blood flow.

enunciado: In the first few days post-liver transplant, what is the most severe vascular complication that can lead to early graft loss?
explicacion_openai: Hepatic artery thrombosis is a devastating complication that compromises the oxygen supply to the graft and can lead to ischemic liver failure.

enunciado: A patient with a femoropopliteal bypass graft presents with decreasing ankle-brachial indices (ABIs) and recurrent leg pain during walking. What is the most likely cause of this graft dysfunction?
explicacion_openai: Stenosis or thrombosis are the most common causes of graft dysfunction, restricting blood flow and causing ischemic symptoms like claudication and decreased ABIs.

enunciado: An operative report for a renal transplant indicates "end-to-end anastomosis of the graft renal artery to the recipient's internal iliac artery." What does this mean for the sonographic examination?
opciones: The sonographer will look for a side-to-side anastomosis between the graft renal artery and the internal iliac artery.
The sonographer will look for an anastomosis where the end of the graft renal artery is connected to the transected end of the internal iliac artery.
The anastomosis will be difficult to visualize due to its deep location.
The graft renal artery will be connected directly to the aorta.
respuesta_correcta: The sonographer will look for an anastomosis where the end of the graft renal artery is connected to the transected end of the internal iliac artery.
explicacion_openai: "End-to-end" means the end of one vessel is joined to the end of another, implying the recipient's internal iliac artery would have been ligated and divided.

enunciado: When scanning a synthetic (e.g., PTFE or GORE-TEX) bypass graft in B-mode, what is its characteristic sonographic appearance?
opciones: Hypoechoic and homogeneous, similar to native vein.
Hyperechoic, double-walled, with echogenic luminal surfaces.
Isoechoic to surrounding tissue, with subtle internal echoes.
An anechoic structure that is difficult to visualize.
respuesta_correcta: Hyperechoic, double-walled, with echogenic luminal surfaces.
explicacion_openai: Synthetic grafts typically appear brightly echogenic with a characteristic double-walled appearance due to their material composition, distinguishing them from native vessels.

enunciado: In a patient post-EVAR, what B-mode finding within the aneurysm sac might indicate an impending Type II endoleak even before color flow is detected?
opciones: The presence of a "swirling" pattern of echoes within the sac.
A sudden decrease in the sac diameter.
A clearly defined, thick calcified wall.
respuesta_correcta: The presence of a "swirling" pattern of echoes within the sac.
explicacion_openai: A "swirling" pattern of echoes (sometimes described as "smoke") can represent slow-moving blood or thrombus within the aneurysm sac, often a precursor or indicator of an endoleak.

enunciado: What is the typical B-mode appearance of a successfully ablated superficial vein (e.g., Great Saphenous Vein) several weeks post-procedure?
opciones: Dilated, anechoic lumen with visible flow.
Hypoechoic or anechoic, collapsed lumen with internal echoes representing thrombosis/fibrosis.
Normal, compressible appearance with spontaneous flow.
respuesta_correcta: Hypoechoic or anechoic, collapsed lumen with internal echoes representing thrombosis/fibrosis.
explicacion_openai: A successfully ablated vein should appear collapsed, often hypoechoic to anechoic with some internal echoes from organized thrombus and fibrosis, indicating successful occlusion.

enunciado: When performing an ultrasound on a patient with a Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt (TIPS), how does the stent typically appear in B-mode within the liver parenchyma?
opciones: Anechoic and difficult to differentiate from liver tissue.
A hyperechoic, tubular structure often casting a subtle shadow.
A hypoechoic structure with indistinct margins.
respuesta_correcta: A hyperechoic, tubular structure often casting a subtle shadow.
explicacion_openai: Stents are metallic or covered metallic devices that appear brightly echogenic (hyperechoic) and tubular in B-mode, often with some posterior shadowing due to their material.

enunciado: Upon B-mode evaluation, a functioning arteriovenous fistula (AVF) will typically show which of the following characteristics?
opciones: A small, compressible vein with thin walls.
A dilated, thick-walled vein, often with palpable thrill/bruit, and usually compressible.
An occluded vein with internal echoes.
A vein with significant perivascular fluid collection.
respuesta_correcta: A dilated, thick-walled vein, often with palpable thrill/bruit, and usually compressible.
explicacion_openai: A mature and functional AVF leads to arterialization of the vein, causing it to dilate and hypertrophy (thicken walls), while remaining compressible unless thrombosed.

enunciado: Which type of dialysis access involves a direct surgical connection between an artery and a vein without synthetic material?
explicacion_openai: An AVF is created by directly joining a native artery to a native vein, whereas an AVG uses a synthetic conduit.

enunciado: In an infrainguinal bypass graft, which material is generally considered to have the best long-term patency rates?
explicacion_openai: Autogenous (patient's own) saphenous vein is generally considered the "gold standard" graft material for its superior long-term patency, especially in bypasses below the knee.

enunciado: What is the primary difference in surgical technique between an "end-to-side" and an "end-to-end" anastomosis?
opciones: End-to-side connects the ends of two vessels, while end-to-end connects the end of one to the side of another.
End-to-side connects the end of one vessel to the side of another, while end-to-end connects the ends of two vessels.
Both techniques involve connecting the ends of two vessels.
Both techniques involve connecting the side of one vessel to the side of another.
respuesta_correcta: End-to-side connects the end of one vessel to the side of another, while end-to-end connects the ends of two vessels.
explicacion_openai: Understanding these terms is crucial for locating the anastomosis during sonographic evaluation.

enunciado: For a renal transplant, the donor renal artery is most commonly anastomosed to which recipient vessel?
explicacion_openai: The external iliac artery is the most common recipient vessel for the renal artery anastomosis in kidney transplantation due to its size and accessibility.

enunciado: What type of stent is typically used in a TIPS procedure to maintain patency between the portal and hepatic venous systems?
explicacion_openai: Covered stents are preferred in TIPS procedures because they reduce the incidence of shunt stenosis and occlusion by preventing tissue ingrowth, which is a common problem with bare metal stents in this location.

enunciado: A patient has an ankle systolic pressure of 90 mmHg and a brachial systolic pressure of 120 mmHg. What is the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)?
explicacion_openai: The ABI is calculated by dividing the highest ankle systolic pressure by the highest brachial systolic pressure. In this case, 90 mmHg / 120 mmHg = 0.75.

enunciado: When performing segmental pressures, what is the impact of using a blood pressure cuff that is too narrow for the limb segment?
opciones: It will result in falsely low pressure readings.
It will result in falsely elevated pressure readings.
It will have no significant effect on the pressure readings.
It will cause the cuff to inflate improperly.
respuesta_correcta: It will result in falsely elevated pressure readings.
concept_to_study: Ability to evaluate effects of limb size and cuff diameter
explicacion_openai: A cuff that is too narrow for the limb circumference will require greater pressure to occlude the artery, leading to falsely elevated pressure readings. Conversely, a cuff that is too wide will result in falsely low readings.

enunciado: Which of the following describes a normal Doppler waveform obtained from a peripheral artery at rest?
opciones: Triphasic with rapid systolic upstroke, diastolic flow reversal, and forward flow in late diastole.
respuesta_correcta: Triphasic with rapid systolic upstroke, diastolic flow reversal, and forward flow in late diastole.
explicacion_openai: A normal arterial Doppler waveform in the peripheral arteries at rest is typically triphasic, characterized by a rapid systolic upstroke, a brief phase of diastolic flow reversal, and a small antegrade flow component in late diastole. This indicates high resistance flow.

enunciado: After a treadmill exercise, a patient's ABI drops from 1.0 to 0.6. This finding is indicative of:
concept_to_study: Knowledge of provocative/exercise maneuvers and their effect on circulation
explicacion_openai: A significant drop in ABI (typically >20% or >0.15-0.20) after exercise is a strong indicator of hemodynamically significant arterial occlusive disease that becomes symptomatic or more severe with increased metabolic demand.

enunciado: Which instrument is specifically designed to assess microcirculatory blood flow and is often used in venous reflux studies?
explicacion_openai: PPG sensors detect changes in blood volume in the microcirculation (skin capillary beds) by emitting infrared light and measuring the reflected light. They are commonly used in physiologic venous exams to assess venous refilling time and reflux.

enunciado: A patient undergoing an arterial duplex has incompressible ankle arteries. Which alternative pressure index should be considered?
explicacion_openai: When ankle arteries are incompressible due to calcification (common in diabetes or end-stage renal disease), ABIs will be falsely elevated and unreliable. The Toe-Brachial Index (TBI) is a valuable alternative, as toe arteries are less prone to calcification.

enunciado: For segmental pressure measurements, the cuff width should ideally be approximately what percentage of the limb circumference?
concept_to_study: Ability to evaluate effects of limb size and cuff diameter
explicacion_openai: For accurate blood pressure measurements, the cuff bladder width should be approximately 40% of the limb circumference, and the length should be at least 80% of the circumference. This ensures proper arterial occlusion without over or underestimation.

enunciado: What is the expected change in a normal peripheral arterial Doppler waveform immediately following reactive hyperemia (post-occlusion)?
opciones: It becomes monophasic with increased antegrade flow and loss of flow reversal.
It shows complete absence of flow.
It becomes biphasic with no change in flow direction.
respuesta_correcta: It becomes monophasic with increased antegrade flow and loss of flow reversal.
concept_to_study: Obtain appropriate diagnostic waveforms/pressures with and without provocative/exercise maneuvers
explicacion_openai: After reactive hyperemia (induced by cuff occlusion and release), the normal peripheral arterial waveform becomes monophasic with a significant increase in antegrade (forward) flow and loss of the diastolic flow reversal component. This is due to maximal vasodilation in response to ischemia.

enunciado: During a stress test for peripheral arterial disease, a normal patient typically experiences:
opciones: No change or a slight increase in ABI.
A rise in ankle pressure but a drop in brachial pressure.
respuesta_correcta: No change or a slight increase in ABI.
concept_to_study: Knowledge of provocative/exercise maneuvers and their effect on circulation
explicacion_openai: In a normal patient, after exercise, the ABI should remain unchanged or slightly increase due to normal compensatory mechanisms that increase blood flow to the exercising muscles without a significant pressure drop across the arteries.

enunciado: To obtain accurate venous PPG diagnostic waveforms, the sensor should be placed on the:
concept_to_study: Knowledge of placement of venous PPG sensors
explicacion_openai: For venous PPG studies, the sensor is typically placed on the plantar aspect of the foot or just above the medial malleolus to monitor the venous capacitance and refilling time of the superficial venous system.

enunciado: When performing venous PPG for reflux, a rapid venous refilling time (e.g., < 20 seconds) in the absence of tourniquet application suggests:
concept_to_study: Obtain appropriate venous photoplethysmography (PPG) diagnostic waveforms
explicacion_openai: A rapid venous refilling time (< 20-25 seconds) indicates that blood is quickly returning to the calf, often due to venous reflux (venous insufficiency), which is an abnormal finding. Without a tourniquet, it could be superficial or deep reflux.

enunciado: In venous PPG, what is the purpose of applying a tourniquet below the knee?
opciones: To occlude the deep venous system.
To eliminate superficial venous reflux and isolate deep system function.
respuesta_correcta: To eliminate superficial venous reflux and isolate deep system function.
concept_to_study: Ability to evaluate effects of tourniquet on hemodynamics
explicacion_openai: Applying a tourniquet below the knee in venous PPG helps to occlude the superficial veins. This allows the sonographer to assess the deep venous system in isolation and differentiate between superficial and deep venous insufficiency.

enunciado: When interpreting PVR (Pulse Volume Recording) waveforms, what finding is consistent with mild arterial disease?
opciones: Normal amplitude, sharp systolic peak, dicrotic notch present.
explicacion_openai: In mild arterial disease, PVR waveforms may show a slightly widened or 'rounded' systolic peak and the dicrotic notch may still be present but blunted. More severe disease leads to dampened, monophasic waveforms and loss of the dicrotic notch.

enunciado: To optimize venous PPG recordings, the patient should ideally be:
opciones: Standing or in a reverse Trendelenburg position.
respuesta_correcta: Standing or in a reverse Trendelenburg position.
explicacion_openai: Venous PPG recordings for reflux assessment are optimized when the patient is in a gravity-dependent position (standing or reverse Trendelenburg). This allows for maximal venous distention and facilitates the demonstration of reflux.

enunciado: What is the primary hemodynamic effect of a pneumatic cuff inflated to suprasystolic pressure on an artery proximal to the measurement site?
concept_to_study: Knowledge of effects of cuff on hemodynamics (arterial)
explicacion_openai: Inflating a pneumatic cuff to suprasystolic pressure completely occludes the artery beneath it, temporarily stopping blood flow. This is fundamental for obtaining accurate pressure measurements and inducing reactive hyperemia.

enunciado: When using a treadmill for an exercise ABI, which specific preset or protocol is important for standardization?
opciones: Standardized speed and incline (e.g., 2 mph, 12% incline).
respuesta_correcta: Standardized speed and incline (e.g., 2 mph, 12% incline).
explicacion_openai: Using a standardized treadmill protocol with consistent speed and incline is crucial for reliable and reproducible exercise ABI results, allowing for accurate comparison with normal values and follow-up studies. This ensures the provocative stimulus is consistent.

enunciado: A normal ankle pressure should be at least what percentage of the highest brachial pressure?
explicacion_openai: A normal ABI is 1.0 or greater (up to ~1.4). This means the ankle pressure should be equal to or slightly higher than the highest brachial pressure. An ABI below 0.90 typically indicates arterial disease.

enunciado: In a patient with suspected arterial occlusive disease, how does the application of a cold environment affect the circulation and subsequent waveform acquisition?
opciones: It induces vasoconstriction, which can worsen or make apparent arterial insufficiency.
It has no effect on peripheral circulation.
respuesta_correcta: It induces vasoconstriction, which can worsen or make apparent arterial insufficiency.
concept_to_study: Knowledge of provocative/exercise maneuvers and their effect on circulation (cold stress)
explicacion_openai: A cold environment causes vasoconstriction. In patients with arterial disease, this can further compromise already reduced blood flow, potentially exacerbating symptoms or revealing disease that might be occult under normal conditions.

enunciado: What is the primary advantage of using a continuous-wave (CW) Doppler probe over a pulsed-wave (PW) Doppler probe for obtaining ankle pressures?
opciones: Ability to precisely define sample volume depth.
Higher sensitivity to detect low-velocity flow.
Allows for measurement of peak systolic velocity without aliasing.
respuesta_correcta: Higher sensitivity to detect low-velocity flow.
explicacion_openai: CW Doppler probes are highly sensitive to detect low-velocity flow, which is crucial for finding the faint arterial signals in the ankles of patients with severe peripheral arterial disease, especially when obtaining ankle pressures. PW Doppler, while providing depth resolution, is more prone to aliasing with higher velocities.

enunciado: Which finding from a venous PPG study, after applying a thigh tourniquet, would suggest isolated deep venous insufficiency?
opciones: Venous refilling time remains rapid (< 20 seconds).
The PPG waveform shows increased amplitude.
respuesta_correcta: Venous refilling time remains rapid (< 20 seconds).
concept_to_study: Obtain appropriate venous photoplethysmography (PPG) diagnostic waveforms (with tourniquets)
explicacion_openai: If the rapid venous refilling time persists even after applying a thigh tourniquet (which occludes superficial reflux), it indicates that the underlying problem is deep venous insufficiency, as superficial reflux has been excluded.

enunciado: During a venous PPG, how can the sonographer optimize the recording quality?
opciones: Place the sensor over bony prominences.
Ensure proper skin contact and minimize patient movement.
Increase the gain setting to maximum.
Use a larger sensor for better signal.
respuesta_correcta: Ensure proper skin contact and minimize patient movement.
explicacion_openai: Optimizing venous PPG recordings involves ensuring good skin contact of the sensor and minimizing patient movement (e.g., foot movement, muscle contraction) to reduce artifact and obtain a stable baseline and consistent waveform changes.

enunciado: Which of the following is an effect of applying a pneumatic cuff and inflating it to arterial occlusive pressures during reactive hyperemia testing?
opciones: Immediate vasoconstriction distal to the cuff.
Decreased metabolic demand in the limb.
concept_to_study: Knowledge of provocative/exercise maneuvers and their effect on circulation
explicacion_openai: Inflating a cuff to occlusive pressures for several minutes in reactive hyperemia testing creates temporary ischemia distal to the cuff. When the cuff is released, the reactive hyperemia response (increased flow and vasodilation) is assessed.

enunciado: For a patient with suspected subclavian steal syndrome, which maneuver is crucial during a physiologic arterial examination of the upper extremities?
concept_to_study: Knowledge of provocative/exercise maneuvers and their effect on circulation
explicacion_openai: For subclavian steal syndrome, arm exercise or elevation can increase the demand for blood flow in the affected arm, potentially worsening the steal phenomenon and causing a significant pressure drop (or change in vertebral artery flow direction) that would be detected during the exam.

enunciado: When performing a venous PPG, the patient is instructed to perform plantar flexion and dorsiflexion of the foot. What is the primary goal of these maneuvers?
opciones: To stimulate the calf muscle pump and empty venous blood from the calf.
respuesta_correcta: To stimulate the calf muscle pump and empty venous blood from the calf.
concept_to_study: Obtain appropriate venous photoplethysmography (PPG) diagnostic waveforms (plantar flexion and dorsiflexion)
explicacion_openai: Plantar flexion and dorsiflexion activate the calf muscle pump, which is crucial for expelling venous blood from the lower leg. This action is essential for assessing venous refilling time and detecting venous insufficiency with PPG.

enunciado: Which preset on an ultrasound system is specifically designed to optimize for arterial waveform analysis by adjusting parameters like PRF and wall filter?
explicacion_openai: Ultrasound systems have application-specific presets that optimize various imaging and Doppler parameters (like PRF, wall filter, gain, dynamic range) for the type of exam being performed. A vascular arterial preset is specifically configured for obtaining high-quality arterial waveforms and images.

enunciado: What is the sonographer’s primary role during manual compression of a pseudoaneurysm?
opciones: Monitor real‑time closure of the neck and disappearance of flow in the sac
Perform surgical repair if compression fails
respuesta_correcta: Monitor real‑time closure of the neck and disappearance of flow in the sac
explicacion_openai: The sonographer must continuously visualize the pseudoaneurysm sac and neck with B‑mode and color/spectral Doppler throughout compression. The goal is to confirm occlusion of the neck and loss of intra‑sac flow, document progressive thrombosis, and detect failure or complications (for example expanding hematoma). Dynamic imaging guides duration and technique of compression and determines whether additional therapy is required.

enunciado: Which pre‑procedure images are essential before thrombin injection of a pseudoaneurysm?
opciones: Only a single color Doppler snapshot
B‑mode to define sac and neck plus color and spectral Doppler to characterize flow
respuesta_correcta: B‑mode to define sac and neck plus color and spectral Doppler to characterize flow
explicacion_openai: Safe thrombin injection requires an anatomical and hemodynamic map: B‑mode identifies sac size, morphology, neck location and nearby structures; color Doppler locates the feeding artery and flow direction through the neck; spectral Doppler can quantify flow velocities if needed. This combined information defines a safe needle trajectory and helps predict risk of thrombin migration or failure.

enunciado: Which is a relative contraindication to thrombin injection for pseudoaneurysm?
opciones: Uncorrected coagulopathy or known allergy to thrombin
respuesta_correcta: Uncorrected coagulopathy or known allergy to thrombin
explicacion_openai: Uncorrected coagulopathy impairs clot formation and increases bleeding risk; allergy to thrombin risks severe reaction. These conditions often require correction or alternative treatment. Absolute contraindications include inaccessible sacs or arterial‑venous fistulae that risk systemic thrombin migration.

enunciado: During ultrasound‑guided venous ablation, what must the sonographer continuously monitor?
opciones: Catheter/fiber position relative to the vein wall during energy delivery
respuesta_correcta: Catheter/fiber position relative to the vein wall during energy delivery
explicacion_openai: Continuous visualization of the device and vein wall is essential to ensure correct apposition, prevent perforation, and detect excessive heating or echogenic changes indicating tissue injury. Monitoring adjacent structures (nerves, artery) prevents collateral damage. Prompt feedback to the operator allows immediate correction.

enunciado: What immediate post‑procedural finding indicates technical success after thrombin injection?
opciones: Persistent color flow in the sac
Absence of sac flow with echogenic thrombus within the sac
Increase in sac size on B‑mode
New bidirectional flow in the feeding artery
respuesta_correcta: Absence of sac flow with echogenic thrombus within the sac
explicacion_openai: Immediate success is confirmed by disappearance of intra‑sac flow on color Doppler and the presence of echogenic material consistent with thrombus in the sac on B‑mode. Persistent flow or enlargement suggests incomplete treatment or complication, requiring further evaluation.

enunciado: What technique best minimizes injury to adjacent structures when guiding a biopsy or drainage?
opciones: Plan the trajectory in B‑mode and use real‑time imaging with dynamic tissue displacement
Increase gain to visualize more tissue
Use color Doppler only without B‑mode
respuesta_correcta: Plan the trajectory in B‑mode and use real‑time imaging with dynamic tissue displacement
explicacion_openai: Real‑time B‑mode planning and needle visualization allow controlled approach and identification of interposed structures. Gentle tissue displacement can move organs or vessels out of the needle path. Color Doppler is complementary to identify vessels, but cannot replace trajectory planning and continuous B‑mode imaging.

enunciado: What is the expected communication pattern between sonographer and surgeon in intraoperative guidance?
opciones: Continuous, clear updates on probe position and findings
Communication only at the end of the case
No communication unless there is a problem
respuesta_correcta: Continuous, clear updates on probe position and findings
explicacion_openai: Effective intraoperative ultrasound requires ongoing, precise communication about probe orientation, depth, landmarks and changing findings. Real‑time dialogue coordinates maneuvers, prevents instrument conflicts, and enables immediate operational decisions based on imaging.

enunciado: Which transducer is preferred for vascular access of superficial vessels?
explicacion_openai: High‑frequency linear probes (e.g., 7–15 MHz) provide superior axial and lateral resolution for superficial structures and optimal needle visualization. Curvilinear or low‑frequency probes penetrate deeper but reduce image and needle detail, increasing procedural difficulty.

enunciado: What should pre‑procedure documentation include?
opciones: B‑mode and Doppler images showing target anatomy, measurements, and relationship to adjacent structures
Only a written note without images
respuesta_correcta: B‑mode and Doppler images showing target anatomy, measurements, and relationship to adjacent structures
explicacion_openai: Comprehensive documentation should include B‑mode images, color and spectral Doppler showing baseline flow, measurements (depth, diameter, sac size), and clips of dynamic relationships. This supports planning, informed consent, legal record‑keeping and comparison for post‑procedural assessment.

enunciado: Which ultrasound finding suggests an immediate post‑procedural complication?
opciones: New expanding hematoma with active color flow or rapid size increase on B‑mode
Minor subcutaneous echogenic change without flow
Increased flow in a distant artery without extravasation
respuesta_correcta: New expanding hematoma with active color flow or rapid size increase on B‑mode
explicacion_openai: An expanding hematoma with active color flow or rapid enlargement indicates ongoing bleeding and potential hemodynamic compromise, requiring urgent intervention. Minor echogenic changes without flow can be monitored but are less urgent.

enunciado: What aseptic practice reduces infection risk during ultrasound‑guided procedures?
opciones: Omitting sterile drapes to save time
Sterile probe cover, sterile gel, and full aseptic technique
Changing gloves intermittently without sterile prep
Using non‑sterile towels for the field
respuesta_correcta: Sterile probe cover, sterile gel, and full aseptic technique
explicacion_openai: Full aseptic technique includes sterile probe covers, sterile gel or single‑use sterile gel packets, sterile drapes, and sterile gloves. Proper handling of the probe cover and avoiding contamination are essential to prevent iatrogenic infections, especially for invasive or deep procedures.

enunciado: Why measure venous diameter before endovenous ablation?
opciones: To select appropriate catheter size and energy settings and plan number of applications
respuesta_correcta: To select appropriate catheter size and energy settings and plan number of applications
explicacion_openai: Vein diameter guides device selection, energy delivery, pullback technique and number of treatment segments. Accurate measurement prevents undertreatment or excessive thermal injury and allows objective follow‑up comparison.

enunciado: How best confirm needle tip intraluminal position before thrombin injection?
opciones: Inject without confirmation and observe clinical effect
Visualize the tip in B‑mode (long or short axis) and confirm with blood aspiration or a small saline bolus under imaging
respuesta_correcta: Visualize the tip in B‑mode (long or short axis) and confirm with blood aspiration or a small saline bolus under imaging
explicacion_openai: Direct ultrasound visualization of the needle tip, with aspiration of blood and/or a small saline test bolus under imaging, confirms intraluminal placement and reduces risk of extravasation of thrombin, which can cause tissue necrosis or embolic events.

enunciado: Which factor increases likelihood of manual compression failure for a pseudoaneurysm?
opciones: Large sac size or systemic anticoagulation
respuesta_correcta: Large sac size or systemic anticoagulation
explicacion_openai: Large sacs and anticoagulation impede clot formation under compression, reducing the likelihood of successful manual thrombosis. Narrow necks and small sacs are more amenable to compression. Patient factors like obesity or movement also influence success.

enunciado: What minimum elements should a post‑procedural report contain?
opciones: Indication, technique, pre/during/post images, measurements, materials used, time and complications
respuesta_correcta: Indication, technique, pre/during/post images, measurements, materials used, time and complications
explicacion_openai: A complete report documents clinical indication, technique, devices and medications used, representative images and clips, measurements, personnel, procedural time, immediate outcome and any complications. This supports continuity of care, quality assurance and medicolegal requirements.

enunciado: Which adjustment reduces the chance of confusing true turbulent flow with artifact in color Doppler?
opciones: Set PRF to maximum without regard to velocities
Adjust PRF for expected velocities, optimize insonation angle, and reduce ROI/gate size
respuesta_correcta: Adjust PRF for expected velocities, optimize insonation angle, and reduce ROI/gate size
explicacion_openai: Appropriate PRF prevents aliasing; optimizing the insonation angle improves velocity sensitivity and reduces off‑axis signals; reducing the ROI or gate localizes sampling to the lumen and minimizes inclusion of wall motion or adjacent flows that can mimic turbulence.

enunciado: What is the risk of placing the spectral sample volume partially in the arterial wall?
opciones: Introduces wall signals and spectral broadening that misrepresent flow
Reduces noise and sharpens the waveform
Affects only color Doppler, not spectral
respuesta_correcta: Introduces wall signals and spectral broadening that misrepresent flow
concept_to_study: Spectral Doppler sample volume and wall artifact
explicacion_openai: Inclusion of wall motion in the sample introduces low‑frequency signals and noise that broaden the spectral envelope and can produce spurious high‑velocity components. Accurate peak velocity measurement requires placing the sample volume centrally within the lumen, aligned with the flow axis.

enunciado: For perivascular injections, which practice protects nearby nerves?
opciones: Real‑time visualization of the needle tip and small incremental boluses while observing tissue displacement
Inject large volumes to ensure spread
respuesta_correcta: Real‑time visualization of the needle tip and small incremental boluses while observing tissue displacement
explicacion_openai: Visualizing the needle tip during slow, incremental injections allows the operator to see tissue planes separate and to detect inadvertent intraneural injection or high‑pressure jets. This approach reduces nerve injury risk compared with blind or high‑pressure bolus injection.

enunciado: Which ultrasound sign suggests unintended embolization or distal migration of injected material?
opciones: New echogenic material or altered flow pattern in downstream vessels
Reduction of flow only at the injection site
respuesta_correcta: New echogenic material or altered flow pattern in downstream vessels
explicacion_openai: Appearance of new echogenic material inside downstream vessels or unexpected changes in distal flow indicates possible migration of particulate material, thrombus, or embolic agent. Early recognition enables prompt clinical escalation to limit consequences.

enunciado: What logistical check must be completed before an ultrasound‑guided vascular procedure?
opciones: Confirm availability of coffee in the room
Availability of sterile supplies, necessary medications (including reversals), trained personnel, and informed consent
Only ensure the room is available
Wait for the device manufacturer representative
respuesta_correcta: Availability of sterile supplies, necessary medications (including reversals), trained personnel, and informed consent
explicacion_openai: Confirming sterile supplies, medications, reversal agents, trained staff, monitoring and written informed consent is essential for safety. Also verify ultrasound machine function, availability of rescue equipment and clear roles for team members.

enunciado: Which ultrasound finding confirms effective venous occlusion after ablation?
opciones: Persistent antegrade flow through treated segment
Echogenic thrombus in the lumen, absence of color flow and altered compressibility
Increase in vessel diameter without thrombus
respuesta_correcta: Echogenic thrombus in the lumen, absence of color flow and altered compressibility
concept_to_study: Confirmation of venous occlusion after ablation
explicacion_openai: Objective sonographic criteria for successful occlusion include an echogenic thrombus filling the lumen, absent color flow in the treated segment and loss or change of compressibility compared with baseline. Symptom improvement is supportive but not a substitute for imaging confirmation.

enunciado: What should the sonographer do immediately if a major complication is detected intra‑procedure?
opciones: Stop, alert the team, document findings, and follow the institution’s complication management protocol
Hide the event from the record
Transfer the patient without informing the team
respuesta_correcta: Stop, alert the team, document findings, and follow the institution’s complication management protocol
explicacion_openai: Immediate cessation of the provoking action, clear communication with the team, and documentation (images and clips) are required. Follow institutional algorithms for hemostasis, escalation, or conversion to other interventions. Prompt action protects the patient and supports appropriate quality reporting.

enunciado: Why record video clips in addition to still images during procedures?
opciones: Video clips are unnecessary and waste space
Dynamic clips show needle movement, tissue response and transient flow changes for audit and education
Video clips replace the written report
respuesta_correcta: Dynamic clips show needle movement, tissue response and transient flow changes for audit and education
concept_to_study: Importance of video clips in procedural documentation
explicacion_openai: Clips capture temporal events (needle advancement, real‑time flow changes, immediate complications) that single images cannot. They are crucial for quality review, teaching, and medicolegal documentation and should be labeled and archived per policy.

enunciado: What electrical safety measure is important during intraoperative ultrasound with energy delivery?
opciones: There are no electrical safety concerns
Verify insulation, grounding and coordinate with anesthesia to avoid burns or interference
Use any cable available without verification
respuesta_correcta: Verify insulation, grounding and coordinate with anesthesia to avoid burns or interference
explicacion_openai: When radiofrequency or laser energy is applied, proper grounding, intact insulation of cables and correct placement of grounding pads are essential. Coordination with anesthesia and OR staff prevents monitoring interference and patient burns. Adherence to device and institutional protocols mitigates electrical hazards.

enunciado: What is the minimum competency expectation for a sonographer participating in ultrasound‑guided procedures?
opciones: Know only basic machine on/off functions
Solid knowledge of anatomy, ultrasound physics, sterile technique, needle guidance, complication recognition and team communication
Only acquire images for others to interpret
Perform procedures unsupervised without further training
respuesta_correcta: Solid knowledge of anatomy, ultrasound physics, sterile technique, needle guidance, complication recognition and team communication
explicacion_openai: Competency encompasses technical imaging skills, understanding of ultrasound physics and artifacts, aseptic technique, needle visualization and guidance strategies, recognition and initial management of complications, and effective intraoperative communication. Ongoing supervised practice and formal competency assessment maintain proficiency.

enunciado: A 65-year-old male presents with acute onset right leg pain and coolness. The initial clinical assessment suggests acute limb ischemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate imaging study to confirm the diagnosis and plan intervention, based on typical Appropriate Use Criteria for vascular emergencies?
opciones: Duplex ultrasound of the affected leg
Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the affected leg
Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) of the affected leg
respuesta_correcta: Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the affected leg
explicacion_openai: For acute limb ischemia, rapid and comprehensive anatomical information of the entire arterial tree, including inflow and runoff, is critical for immediate surgical or interventional planning. While duplex ultrasound is a primary vascular imaging tool, CTA often provides a faster and more complete assessment in an emergency setting, offering detailed anatomical localization and extent of disease. ABI is a diagnostic tool but doesn't provide anatomical localization for intervention. MRA, while excellent, might take longer to acquire, has specific contraindications (e.g., metallic implants), and may not be as readily available in an acute emergency. (Refer to ACC/AHA Appropriate Use Criteria for Peripheral Arterial Disease and standard vascular surgery texts like "Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy").

enunciado: A patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is scheduled for a carotid duplex ultrasound as part of a routine screening program, despite being asymptomatic and having no bruits. According to widely accepted Appropriate Use Criteria (AUC) for carotid artery imaging, what is the appropriateness rating for this specific scenario?
explicacion_openai: Routine screening for carotid artery stenosis in asymptomatic individuals without specific, strong risk factors (e.g., known severe peripheral artery disease, abdominal aortic aneurysm, or bruits on examination) is generally considered "Rarely Appropriate" by most Appropriate Use Criteria. The potential harms (false positives, patient anxiety, unnecessary further diagnostic tests or interventions) often outweigh the benefits in this low-risk group. AUC guidelines emphasize targeting imaging to patients with higher pre-test probability of significant disease. (Refer to ACC/AHA Appropriate Use Criteria for Carotid Artery Imaging and AIUM practice guidelines).

enunciado: During a lower extremity arterial duplex exam, the sonographer notices the patient is shivering excessively, which is causing significant artifact in the spectral Doppler waveforms. What is the most appropriate initial action for the sonographer to take to ensure optimal patient care and image quality?
opciones: Increase the Doppler gain and filter settings.
Instruct the patient to try and stop shivering forcefully.
Cover the patient with a warm blanket and offer a brief pause.
Complete the exam quickly to minimize patient discomfort.
respuesta_correcta: Cover the patient with a warm blanket and offer a brief pause.
explicacion_openai: Patient comfort directly impacts cooperation and image quality. Shivering can introduce significant motion artifact into Doppler waveforms and B-mode images, making them non-diagnostic. Addressing the root cause (coldness) by providing warmth and offering a brief break demonstrates empathy, improves the patient's experience, and is the most effective way to achieve diagnostic image quality. Increasing gain/filter might mask artifact but won't solve the underlying issue. Forcefully instructing a shivering patient is generally ineffective and can worsen discomfort. Rushing the exam may compromise quality. (Refer to AIUM practice guidelines and general principles of patient-centered care in sonography).

enunciado: A sonographer is preparing to perform a carotid duplex ultrasound on an elderly patient who appears confused and is unable to follow complex instructions. What is the best approach to ensure the patient's safety and cooperation during the exam?
opciones: Proceed with the exam as quickly as possible, minimizing interaction.
Attempt to explain each step in medical terminology to improve understanding.
Speak clearly, use simple language, and demonstrate positions, seeking assistance if needed.
Administer a sedative to the patient to ensure stillness.
respuesta_correcta: Speak clearly, use simple language, and demonstrate positions, seeking assistance if needed.
explicacion_openai: For confused, elderly, or uncooperative patients, clear, simple, and concise communication is paramount. Using plain language and demonstrating desired positions (e.g., "turn your head like this") can be far more effective than complex verbal instructions. Seeking assistance from a nurse, family member, or another healthcare professional can ensure both patient safety (e.g., preventing falls, maintaining position) and the successful completion of the exam. Sedation is not a routine first-line approach in a diagnostic imaging setting and would require a physician's order and monitoring. (Refer to AIUM practice guidelines and patient communication strategies for vulnerable populations).

enunciado: A referring physician orders a renal artery duplex ultrasound for a patient with newly diagnosed, uncomplicated hypertension, without any other risk factors for renovascular disease or signs of resistant hypertension. Based on current Appropriate Use Criteria for renal artery stenosis, how would this order generally be classified?
opciones: Appropriate, as it's a primary screening tool for all hypertension.
May Be Appropriate, depending on local protocols.
Rarely Appropriate, as this scenario typically does not warrant initial renal artery imaging.
Indeterminate, requiring further diagnostic tests first.
respuesta_correcta: Rarely Appropriate, as this scenario typically does not warrant initial renal artery imaging.
explicacion_openai: Current Appropriate Use Criteria for renal artery duplex ultrasound generally recommend screening for renovascular hypertension in patients with specific high-risk indicators such as resistant hypertension (uncontrolled on three or more anti-hypertensive drugs), sudden onset of hypertension at a young or old age, worsening renal function on ACE inhibitors or ARBs, unexplained asymmetric kidney size, or recurrent flash pulmonary edema/unexplained congestive heart failure. Uncomplicated, newly diagnosed hypertension without these features is considered low probability for renal artery stenosis and typically does not warrant initial renal artery imaging due to the low diagnostic yield and potential for false positives. (Refer to ACC/AHA Appropriate Use Criteria for Renal Artery Imaging).

enunciado: A 55-year-old male presents with claudication symptoms after walking 200 meters. A prior ABI study showed abnormal values. The physician now orders a lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound. Applying Appropriate Use Criteria, this order would be considered:
opciones: Rarely Appropriate, as ABI is sufficient for diagnosis.
May Be Appropriate, but CTA or MRA are preferred.
Appropriate, as it provides anatomical and hemodynamic information.
Indeterminate, requiring a treadmill test first.
respuesta_correcta: Appropriate, as it provides anatomical and hemodynamic information.
concept_to_study: AUC for lower extremity arterial duplex
explicacion_openai: When claudication symptoms are present and an abnormal Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) confirms the presence of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD), a lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound is an appropriate next step. The duplex provides crucial anatomical localization of stenoses or occlusions and a hemodynamic assessment of their severity, which is essential for guiding treatment planning (e.g., angioplasty, stenting, bypass surgery). While CTA and MRA also provide anatomical detail, duplex ultrasound is often preferred as a non-invasive, cost-effective, and functional imaging modality. A treadmill test might be used to quantify functional limitation, but the duplex is key for anatomical diagnosis. (Refer to ACC/AHA Appropriate Use Criteria for Peripheral Arterial Disease Imaging and SVU practice guidelines).

enunciado: A patient undergoes a carotid duplex ultrasound that reveals a highly stenotic internal carotid artery lesion (70-80% stenosis) with significant post-stenotic turbulence. A follow-up MRA of the neck shows a similar degree of stenosis but suggests a longer, more irregular plaque. What is the most likely reason for potential discrepancies between duplex and MRA findings in this scenario?
opciones: Duplex ultrasound overestimates stenosis in tortuous vessels.
MRA is inherently less accurate for assessing plaque morphology.
Differences in measurement techniques and the ability of each modality to visualize specific plaque characteristics (e.g., calcification, soft plaque components).
The patient's blood pressure significantly changed between the two studies.
respuesta_correcta: Differences in measurement techniques and the ability of each modality to visualize specific plaque characteristics (e.g., calcification, soft plaque components).
concept_to_study: Correlation of duplex and MRA findings
explicacion_openai: Both duplex ultrasound and MRA are valuable for assessing carotid stenosis, but they have different strengths and limitations. Duplex ultrasound relies on Doppler flow characteristics and B-mode visualization of lumen reduction, which can be affected by severe calcification (shadowing) or vessel tortuosity. MRA provides a 3D view of the lumen and can be less susceptible to shadowing from calcification, offering a more comprehensive view of plaque length and irregularity. However, MRA can sometimes overestimate stenosis in areas of slow or turbulent flow. Discrepancies often arise from these inherent differences in how each modality measures the lumen, visualizes plaque morphology (e.g., distinguishing soft plaque from thrombus, or seeing intraplaque hemorrhage), and handles artifacts. Significant blood pressure changes could alter hemodynamics but are less likely to cause fundamental differences in plaque characterization between two studies performed relatively close in time. (Refer to "Clinical Vascular Ultrasound" by Khan and Daigle, and "Vascular Technology: An Illustrated Review" by King and Rader).

enunciado: A deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is suspected in a patient with acute leg swelling. A lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound is performed, which is negative for DVT. However, the patient's D-dimer is significantly elevated, and clinical suspicion remains high. Which of the following subsequent actions is most appropriate in correlating findings with other modalities or further workup?
opciones: Immediately repeat the duplex ultrasound by a different sonographer.
Discharge the patient, as a negative duplex definitively rules out DVT.
Consider a CT venography or serial duplex ultrasounds if clinical suspicion persists.
Prescribe anticoagulants empirically based on the D-dimer alone.
respuesta_correcta: Consider a CT venography or serial duplex ultrasounds if clinical suspicion persists.
concept_to_study: Correlation of DVT findings with other modalities
explicacion_openai: A negative venous duplex ultrasound, especially when combined with a highly elevated D-dimer and strong clinical suspicion (high pre-test probability), warrants further investigation. While duplex is highly sensitive for proximal DVT, small calf DVTs or non-occlusive thrombi can sometimes be missed, or the DVT could be in an area not fully visualized. In such cases, a CT venography (which can visualize the entire deep venous system and alternative pathologies) or serial duplex ultrasounds (e.g., 3-7 days later) to check for thrombus propagation are appropriate. Repeating the duplex immediately by a different sonographer may or may not yield different results. Discharging the patient or empirically prescribing anticoagulants without definitive imaging in this scenario would be inappropriate and potentially dangerous. (Refer to ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Suspected DVT and SVU practice guidelines for Venous Duplex).

enunciado: For a standard carotid duplex ultrasound protocol, which of the following is typically NOT a required measurement or assessment?
opciones: Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) of the Common Carotid Artery (CCA).
Assessment of the vertebral artery flow direction.
Measurement of carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) for routine stenosis evaluation.
respuesta_correcta: Measurement of carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) for routine stenosis evaluation.
